STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER FARAH A. HANLEY
LANSING
GOVERNOR ACTING DIRECTOR
January 17, 2019
Jennifer Tate, Director
Livingston County DHHS
Suite 1
2300 E. Grand River
Howell, MI 48843-7577
RE: License #: CP470201250
Livingston County DHHS
Suite 1
2300 E. Grand River
Howell, MI 48843-7577
Dear Ms. Tate:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 12/20/2018.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
Courtney Smith Atkins, Program Manager
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

License #: CP470201250
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768

Facility Address: Suite 1
2300 E. Grand River
Howell, MI 48843-7577
Facility Telephone #: (517) 548-0200
Original Issuance Date: 04/15/1993

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent/agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
(1) (b) In one of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation in the record stating that the foster parent was willing to
accept the foster child.
(1) (c) In one of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation indicating that a copy of the initial evaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(1) (d) In one of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation that a copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(1) (f) In one of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation that the foster parent has received orientation to the policies
of the borrowing agency.
(1) (g) In one of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation that a copy of the foster parent/agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
4

(6) (a) In one of three special investigations reviewed, one did not have
documentation that a copy of the report was provided to the foster parent 10
calendar days of its completion.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in
R400.12417 (1) and all of the following information:
(a) All of the following child characteristics:
(iv) Eye color and hair color.
(7) (a) (iv) In one of nine children’s records reviewed, one did not have
documentation that he child’s eye color was documented within 7 calendar days
after placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL INSPECTION
NOVEMBER 2017.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the reason
why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with
relative, then the reason why those placements are not possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R 400.12404 (4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s age,
appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer guardian
ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417.
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the change,
except when prior notification would jeopardize the child’s care or
safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the agency shall notify
the foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior notice was
not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning the change in
placement.
5

(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
(3) (a-J) In one of nine foster children’s records reviewed, there was no
documentation in the foster child’s record stating the required information in the rule.
The MDHHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary was not in the case
record when the foster child placement changed. No information was uploaded in
MiSACWIS.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL INSPECTION
NOVEMBER 2017.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(2) (a) In one of nine children’s records reviewed, one child did not have a written
initial service plan within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS.
MiSACWIS
(Commitment
22)
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (MiSACWIS) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
The agency was reminded that all documentation must be completed and uploaded
in MiSACWIS including DHS 69s, service plans, PATPs, licensing closing BCAL
3706, medical passports, immunization records and FTM activity reports, etc.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
6

MDHHS Policy Family Team Meetings
FOM 722-6B
Pg.2
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
 Case service plans development
 Permanency goal changes
 Placement preservation/disruption
 Permanency planning at six months in care annual
transition planning for youth every six months from age 16
until case closure
 90-day discharge planning for youth
 Case closure
One out of nine case records reviewed did not have documentation that an FTM
was completed for the child’s ISP service plan development.
MDHHS Policy Supervisory Approval
FOM 722-09
Pg. 25
The caseworker’s supervisor must review, approve, and sign the
initial service plan within fourteen days, after a face to face
meeting with the caseworker.
One out of nine case records reviewed did not contain supervisory approval. The
case record had three draft reports neither was signed by the supervisor.
MDHHS Policy Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
FOM 722-08C Agreement (Signatures)
For both ISP and USP, the PATP must be signed by the worker,
supervisor, parent (s), foster parents/caregivers, and children 14
years and older.
7

Two of nine case records reviewed the PATP were not signed by the worker,
supervisor, parent and or foster parents/caregiver.
One of the case records reviewed updated service plan dated 07/04/18 –
10/01/2018 the PATP was mailed out on 12/19/2018.
MDHHS Policy Medical Passports
FOM 801
Pg. 14
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided to the foster care provider within two weeks of the
child's placement date. The actual date the foster care provider
receive the medical passport must be documented in MiSACWIS
All medical information within the medical passport must be current
and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's current and
complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the necessary
information under law and MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
One out of nine case records reviewed, one foster child record did not contain a
medical passport for the child.
REPEAT VIOLATION FROM RENEWAL INSPECTION
NOVEMBER 2017.
MDHHS Policy Personnel Training
SRM 200
All personnel, contractors, vendors and external auditors who have
access to CW-CHRI are required to complete security awareness training
(SAT). Training will be available on the Learning Management System
(LMS) for MDHHS personnel and contractors with access to this system.
8

SAT is required to be taken within six months of being in a position with
CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible
for ensuring that all personnel with CHRI access completes the SAT.
DCWL consultants will monitor completion of SAT in all CPAs as part of
the annual licensing audit.
CI-182a was released to the field in December of 2016 advising all current
employees with access to CHRI to complete SAT training no later than
02/10/2017. All other employees hired after December of 2016 were
required to complete SAT according to the policy.
Three current employees were found in non-compliance to timely completion of
SAT training. One employee position hired date was 7/24/20111, she completed
the training on 08/01/2017. One employee position hired date was 11/25/2013,
she completed the training on 7/2/2018. Bothe employee was late with their SAT
training. One employee position hire date was 2/29/16. There was no record of
SAT in LMS.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s November 2017 Renewal
inspection. At that time, the agency received several rules, ISEP and policy
violations. The agency made progress with its correction plan for that inspection.
There was a decrease in the number of licensing rule violations, ISEP and DHHS
Policy. The agency has three repeat violations from its renewal 2017 inspection.
The second corrective action plan is related to Special Investigation 2018C0207020.
The investigation related to an allegation that a worker reported information that a
resident was not provided sufficient clothing. The agency received a citation for
R400.12206 (1) Staff qualification. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective
action plan that indicated there was a misrepresentation of facts of the allegation and
both DHHS and the private agency was found in non-compliant with the above-
9

mentioned rule. The special investigation was closed on 06/07/2018 and there was
no changes in the current license status.
There have been no repeat violations of the rules identified in the stated special
investigation. The agency remains in compliance with this corrective action plan.
DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety Alert #1:
Concern:
Foster parent reported not being able to provide input or sign case service plan.
Resolution:
This home was used as an Emergency Placement only. The longest stay in the home
was 20 days, at which time feedback was obtained to assist in securing a placement for
a longer time span. The foster family would not have signed a service plan as they did
not have placement at the time that these would have been completed.
Safety Alert #5:
Concern:
Relative reported never participating in at least one family team meeting.
Resolution:
Relative began as child’s caregiver on 5/18/18.
Relative was invited to FTM’s held on the following dates: 5/10/18, 6/11/18, 9/12/18,
invited on 9/7/18 face to face and 12/3/18 invited on 11/16/18 via phone and text.
Safety Alert #6
Concern:
Relative reported not participating in at least one family team meeting and the children not
having parenting time. Relative reported foster care worker visited home only 3 times in six
months and made no unannounced home visits. Relative reported not receiving a medical
passport and not signing the case service plan. Foster children reported not participating in
semi-transitional meetings and not being involved in the development of their service plan.
Birth father reported not being involved in decisions regarding medical needs and not
participating in parenting time.
Resolution:
FTM: The family participated in an FTM on 09/24/2018 regarding becoming licensed.
An FTM was scheduled at DHHS for everyone on 10/12/2018. DHHS invited the
relatives however they or the parents did not show up.
Parenting time: The courts suspended parenting time for a period of time due to the
termination petition. They are currently having parenting time with the mother on
10

Tuesday’s during therapy. The court order states parenting time in a therapeutic setting
only.
Home visits: The following home visits took place over the last 6 months unannounced
visits are marked: 11/19/2018, 10/10/2018 -unannounced, 09/24/2018, 08/02/2018,
07/23/2018 – unannounced, 06/28/2018 – unannounced 06/21/2018. 05/11/2018 and
05/04/2018.
The following Medical passports were signed by the placement 10/10/2018 and
09/24/2018.
Service plans: the following service plans were signed by the relatives on 09/24/2018.
Semi transition meeting: A semi-annual transition plan occurred with child 1 on
10/10/2018.
Father parenting time: supervised in a therapeutic setting only one visit occurred with
child 1. Both girls continue to refuse visits with their father. Recently the court ordered
that the children shall not be forced to engage in parenting time with any respondent.
Father medical participation: Father consented to psychotropic medication for child 2.
He has also been provided and signed the last two medical passports.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Livingston County DHHS
continue on a regular license.
01/15/2019
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 16, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
